facts.text: Purnabai widow of Sagarmal Mody held three deposit receipts of aggregate face value Rs. 6,26,724-14-0 with State Bank of Bikaner on April 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Purnabai widow of Sagarmal Mody held on April 1, 1953 three deposit receipts of the aggregate face value of Rs. 6,26,724-14-0 with the State Bank

facts.text: Purnabai informed the Bank by letter dated July 22, 1952 that she intended to gift amounts of two receipts to Suryakant son of her adopted son Satyanarayana.

anchor.surface_text: By her letter dated July 22, 1952 Purnabai informed the Bank that she intended to make a gift of the amounts of two out of the three receipts to Suryakant

facts.text: Purnabai requested Bank to renew receipts for three months in joint names of Purnabai Sagarmal Mody and or Surya Kant S. Mody payable to either or survivor.

concepts.unlisted_description: Property taken under any gift deemed to pass on donor's death if bona fide possession and enjoyment not immediately assumed by donee to entire exclusion of donor or benefit to donor, subject to two-year proviso.

anchor.surface_text: s. 10 of the Estate Duty Act 34 of 1953. Section 10 of that Act provides Property taken under any gift, whenever made, shall be deemed to pass on the donors death to the extent that bona fide possession and enjoyment of it was not immediately assumed by the donee and thenceforward retained to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him by contract or otherwise Provided that the property shall not be deemed to pass by reason only that it was not, as from the date of the gift, exclusively retained as aforesaid, if by means of the surrender of the reserved benefit or otherwise, it is subsequently enjoyed to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him for at least two years before the death.

concepts.interpretation: If bona fide possession and enjoyment not immediately assumed by donee to entire exclusion of donor, property included in estate for duty; donor retained control via joint receipts.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: somewhat involved. The purport of the section is however clear. The section clearly means that if in respect of any property which is gifted, bona fi

concepts.unlisted_description: Deems gifted property to pass on death absent exclusive possession by donee; two-year surrender proviso.

arguments.claim: bona fide possession and enjoyment of it was not immediately assumed by the donee and thenceforward retained to the entire exclusion of the donor ... property ... deemed to pass

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 of that Act provides Property taken under any gift, whenever made, shall be deemed to pass on the donors death to the extent that bona fide possession and enjoyment of it was not immediately assumed by the donee and thenceforward retained to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him by contract or otherwise

arguments.claim: donee Suryakant did not under the deed of gift immediately assume bona fide possession and enjoyment of the fixed deposit receipts ... to the entire exclusion of Purnabai

anchor.surface_text: The question which must be determined therefore is whether in the present case the donee Suryakant did under the deed of gift immediately assume bona fide possession and enjoyment of the fixed deposit receipts gifted to him, and thenceforward retained the same to the entire exclusion of Purnabai or of any benefit arising to her by contract or otherwise.

arguments.claim: Purnabai had no intention to part with control over the property ... had authority to withdraw the amount ... without consulting the guardian ... presented ... for renewal ... could ... receive the moneys to the entire exclusion of Suryakant

anchor.surface_text: The conduct of Purnabai clearly indicates that she had no intention to part with control over the property the deposit receipts were obtained in joint names, and Purnabai had authority to withdraw the amount from the Bank, without consulting the guardian of Suryakant. The deposit receipts were renewed on several occasions even after the execution of the deed of gift in the joint. names of Purnabai and Suryakant. Purnabai alone presented the fixed deposit recepits for renewal. She could under the terms of the receipts receive the moneys to the entire exclusion of Suryakant.

arguments.claim: right retained by Purnabai to have the receipts made out in her name jointly ... power to recover the amount ... without the concurrence of Suryakant clearly indicate that she was not excluded, but she had retained important benefits

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold, in the circumstances, that bona fide possession and enjoyment of the property gifted was immediately assumed by Suryakant and thenceforward retained by him to the entire exclusion of Purnabai. The right retained by Purnabai to have the receipts made out in her name jointly with Suryakant and the power to recover the amount from the Bank without the concurrence of Suryakant clearly indicate that she was not excluded, but she had retained important benefits in herself in the fixed deposit receipts.

arguments.claim: no evidence that in obtaining the receipts in the joint names Purnabai acted as a guardian of Suryakant or that she was a benamidar of Suryakant

anchor.surface_text: There is also no evidence that in obtaining the receipts in the joint names Purnabai acted as a guardian of Suryakant or that she was a benamidar of Suryakant.

arguments.claim: High Court was right in answering the question against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the High Court was right in answering the question against the appellant.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in answering the question against the appellant: the sum of Rs. 6,85,193/- was correctly included in the estate of the deceased as property deemed to pass on her death under section 10 of the Estate Duty Act, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the High Court was right in answering the question against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Donee failed to immediately assume bona fide possession and enjoyment to the donor's entire exclusion, as donor retained control through joint deposit receipts, sole renewal authority, and discharge rights; confirmed lower courts' application of s.10.

holdings.text: Bona fide possession and enjoyment of the property gifted was not immediately assumed by Suryakant and thenceforward retained by him to the entire exclusion of Purnabai.

anchor.surface_text: The conduct of Purnabai clearly indicates that she had no intention to part with control over the property the deposit receipts were obtained in joint names, and Purnabai had authority to withdraw the amount from the Bank, without consulting the guardian of Suryakant. The deposit receipts were renewed on several occasions even after the execution of the deed of gift in the joint. names of Purnabai and Suryakant. Purnabai alone presented the fixed deposit recepits for renewal. She could under the terms of the receipts receive the moneys to the entire exclusion of Suryakant. We are unable to hold, in the circumstances, that bona fide possession and enjoyment of the property gifted was immediately assumed by Suryakant and thenceforward retained by him to the entire exclusion of Purnabai. The right retained by Purnabai to have the receipts made out in her name jointly with Suryakant and the power to recover the amount from the Bank without the concurrence of Suryakant clearly indicate that she was not excluded, but she had retained important benefits in herself in the fixed deposit receipts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Donor's post-gift conductobtaining renewals in joint names, presenting receipts alone for renewal, authority to withdraw without donee's concurrenceshows retention of control and benefits, preventing exclusive possession by donee under s.10 test.

holdings.text: There is no evidence that Purnabai acted as a guardian of Suryakant or that she was a benamidar of Suryakant.

anchor.surface_text: There is also no evidence that in obtaining the receipts in the joint names Purnabai acted as a guardian of Suryakant or that she was a benamidar of Suryakant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's claim of benami holding unsupported by any evidence; donor's actions inconsistent with benami or guardian role.

holdings.text: The argument that fixed deposit receipts had remained exclusively in the possession of Satyanarayana as guardian of Suryakant and they were obtained by him from Purnabai for the purpose of renewal is not supported by any evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that fixed deposit receipts had remained exclusively in the possession of Satyanarayana as guardian of Suryakant and they were obtained by him from Purnabai for the purpose of renewal is not supported by any evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidentiary support for claim of exclusive possession by donee's guardian post-gift.

holdings.text: The encashment and reinvestment of the third receipt were within two years of the death of Purnabai and the amounts so reinvested were liable to be included in the estate of Purnabai.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the third receipt was encashed during the life time of Purnabai, and the amount was invested in the name of Suryakant alone. But the encashment and reinvestment were within two years of the death of Purnabai and the amounts so reinvested were liable to be included in the estate of Purnabai.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.10 does not apply as exclusive enjoyment not retained for at least two years prior to death; reinvestment within two years triggers inclusion.

precedents.citation: Imperial Bank of India, Madras v. Krishnamurthi and another A.I.R. 1933 Madras, 628.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel invited our attention to a decision of the Madras High Court in Imperial Bank of India, Madras v. Krishnamurthi and another 1  in which Beasely, C.J. speaking for the Court observed that when a Bank having notice that the administrators of the estate of the depositor intended to commit a breach of trust by seeking to invest monies contrary to express directions of the will paid out the money, the Bank was liable to make good to the beneficiary

precedents.case_name: Imperial Bank of India, Madras v. Krishnamurthi and another
precedents.cited_proposition: A bank having notice that its customer holds money in a fiduciary capacity cannot part with the money at the customer's direction for purposes inconsistent with the fiduciary duty
precedents.cited_holding: when a Bank having notice that the administrators of the estate of the depositor intended to commit a breach of trust by seeking to invest monies contrary to express directions of the will paid out the money, the Bank was liable to make good to the beneficiary the money deposited by the testator

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the High Court was right in answering the question against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: e entire exclusion of Purnabai or of any benefit arising to her by companytract or otherwise. The companyduct of Purnabai clearly indicates that she h

edges.explanation: h2 directly finds that Suryakant did not immediately assume bona fide possession to entire exclusion, addressing i2

anchor.surface_text: The conduct of Purnabai clearly indicates that she had no intention to part with control over the property the deposit receipts were obtained in joint names, and Purnabai had authority to withdraw the amount from the Bank, without consulting the guardian of Suryakant. The deposit receipts were renewed on several occasions even after the execution of the deed of gift in the joint. names of Purnabai and Suryakant. Purnabai alone presented the fixed deposit recepits for renewal. She could under the terms of the receipts receive the moneys to the entire exclusion of Suryakant. We are unable to hold, in the circumstances, that bona fide possession and enjoyment of the property gifted was immediately assumed by Suryakant and thenceforward retained by him to the entire exclusion of Purnabai. The right retained by Purnabai to have the receipts made out in her name jointly with Suryakant and the power to recover the amount from the Bank without the concurrence of Suryakant clearly indicate that she was not excluded, but she had retained important benefits in herself in the fixed deposit receipts.
We are of the view that the High Court was right in answering the question against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the third receipt was encashed during the life time of Purnabai, and the amount was invested in the name of Suryakant alone. But the encashment and reinvestment were within two years of the death of Purnabai and the amounts so reinvested were liable to be included in the estate of Purnabai.
